messages: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:08): we should organize a WHATCAMP; a place for developers and standards people to meet
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:08): (not my idea)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:09): I get the feeling there's a lot of subtle things we can change that would improve the web for everyone
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:09): having met with some developers in the past week
6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf (00:16): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: hopefully somewhere in Europe
6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf (00:16): but yes, sounds like a good idea
6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf (00:17): Opera could arrange it... Oslo perhaps? I haven't been there :)
6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf (00:20): might be easier to arrange it in Brussels close to Fosdem, like couple of days before Fosdem
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:20): that does not sound too bad
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:21): I think we should have it in the bay area too, but experimenting closer to home works better for me :)
6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf (00:22): is all for trying to make technology world less US centric
6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf (00:23): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: perhaps Opera and Mozilla Europe could arrange something together.
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:24): what do you guys think about http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=14364 ?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:24): yeah
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:25): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: there's a lot of interest here
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:25): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: pretty much everyone dealing with appcache also wants dynamic; but it's kind of dinstict
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:26): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: appcache is atomic, this is somewhat separate from that
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:26): wycats had these notes:
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:26): window.localResources.add(url, callback) => window.localResources.remove(url) => window.localResources.update(url, callback)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:26): window.localResource.on("update", callback)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:27): I think sicking thinks this should be solved using Indexed DB
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:27): download first and then store it in the database
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:27): but that seems less convenient as you cannot keep using URLs at that point
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:28): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: does that help?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:29): so sicking thinks appcache shouldn't be used at all?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:30): app cache is what is required to make your app run offline
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:30): resources on top of that such as media or large amounts of email is typically stored in different ways
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:31): e.g. for email attachments it seems sensible to store them in Indexed DB
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:31): but there is probably room between the two for cached URLs
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:32): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905: hey
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:32): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905: so I'm just using macports
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:32): greetings
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:34): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905: updated the spec just now
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:34): hg clone, hg pull, hg update, hg commit, hg push
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:35): it's "fairly" trivial
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:35): ah ok - sounds not too different than git
6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf (00:38): obviously f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 should do some gecko development to get used to hg
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:38): he does work for Mozilla... :p
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:40): btw f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905, see the logs for "WHATCAMP"; standards/developers/browsers
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:42): ooh that sounds like a good idea
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:42): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e - I took a look at the draft, we want the OWFa statement to autoupdate as well
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:42): s/4 November 2011/[DATE: 01 Jan 1901]
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:43): ok who will be the one to save <hgroup>?
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:43): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 - I'm considering it
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:43): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905: oh I didn't realize that
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:43): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e - that way it indicates that we've agreed to OWFa on the very latest draft
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:44): also fixed
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:44): I like <hgroup> semantically, and am unsure about the usefulness of its impact on the outline algorithm
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:45): I'm considering writing up a change proposal just to keep the semantics part, and drop the impact on the outline algorithm.
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:45): I'm wondering if there are enough people that would care however.
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:45): Because if I'm the only one that cares then it doesn't make sense to save hgroup.
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:46): wait what? impacting the outline algorithm is the semantic <hgroup> has!
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:46): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905: I want to use it for my specs at least
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:47): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905: afaik people want to keep it and I doubt it will be dropped across both specs...
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:47): nobody has written a no-change CP

f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:49): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 - the use-case of having it impact the outline algorithm which then would affect things like tables of contents - is not described as it is used in practice.
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:49): e.g. in a book with a title with subhead, or a chapter title with subhead, the text of both is grouped and shown together, rather than hidden
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:49): rather than the subhead being hidden that is
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:50): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 - if you'd like to work together on a change proposal - I'm for it
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:50): feel free to get started and I'll contribute
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:50): the subhead doesn't need to be hidden in the ToC, i think
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:51): the <hgroup> is the heading, and it just gets its *rank* from the highest ranked h* child
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:51): what text to use in the ToC is not defined
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:52): is working on a few change proposals already (enhanced time, keep/introduce data, etc.)
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:53): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 that wasn't my understanding - but I can re-read the spec.
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:54): hmm. seems i was wrong.

cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:54): "For the purposes of document summaries, outlines, and the like, the text of hgroup elements is defined to be the text of the highest ranked h1‚Äìh6 element descendant of the hgroup element, if there are any such elements, and the first such element if there are multiple elements with that rank. If there are no such elements, then the text of the hgroup element is the empty string."
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:54): i think that should be considered a UI issue and not restricted like that
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:54): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 - what you described above (not quoted) is the effect I want because that's what I've seen happen in outlines/ToCs
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:54): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 - I would be happy with that too.

cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:58): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905: if the effect hgroup has was removed from the outline algo altogether, then <hgroup><h1></h1><h2></h2></hgroup> would create two *sections*, which is not wanted
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:58): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 - aha I see what you mean
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:59): In practice, semantic subheads are joined with their heading using some sort of combination character.
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:59): http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Diamond_Age
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:59): i don't have time right now to write a CP (have to sleep), but i'd suggest no-change CP except loosen the paragraph quoted above
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (01:01): (rationale: what text to use in ToC etc is a UI issue, and the spec usually doesn't restrict UI choices)
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:02): effectively has <hgroup><h1>The Diamond Age</h1> <h2>Or, A Young Lady's Illustrated Primer</h1></hgroup>
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (01:02): back later
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:02): but when the h1 and h2 are combined, they're combined with a ":"
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:02): The Diamond Age: Or, A Young Lady's Illustrated Primer
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:02): ttyl edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:03): thus it would be particularly useful if <hgroup> allowed for specifying how to join the headings when making a single string
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (01:03): that smells like overengineering to me :)
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:03): I don't have a specific suggestion except perhaps a combiner attribute that takes a string to insert between the different heading children
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:03): perhaps
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:03): we can mention it as considered and rejected too.
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (01:04): would keep it simple
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (01:04): if you write a CP, i'm happy to review it tomorrow
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (01:05): or maybe i can write one tomorrow if you don't
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:05): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 - tomorrow is fine - go ahead and start one
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:05): I would but I'm already working on two
